block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Focus on Vietnam M.I.A.'s During Clinton Visit President Clinton drove into the Vietnamese countryside to find the site where an American flyer on a bombing run was downed by anti-aircraft fire 33 years ago. The visit was intended as a vivid demonstration of how Americans and Vietnamese are working together to finish the emotionally draining business of accounting for 1,498 Americans still listed as missing in action.

Bitter Politics in Taiwan The bitter political stalemate between Taiwan's President and his opposition veered into soap opera, with the news dominated first by an unproven ''Monica Lewinsky'' scandal, then by an allegation, also denied, that his own vice president had spread the story.

Palestinian Attacks Israeli Post A Palestinian security officer sprayed gunfire on an Israeli Army post in the Gaza Strip, killing one soldier and wounding two more before being shot dead by return fire, an Israeli military spokesman said.

New Era in Yugoslavia The postrevolutionary billboards of Belgrade are mostly commercial again, except a new poster sponsored by the student movement showing a bulldozer and the slogan ''We are still watching,'' a warning to the new authorities gathered awkwardly around the new president, Vojislav Kostunica.

Haitian Officers Sentenced A Haitian court has sentenced a former coup leader, Raoul Cedras, and 36 other military officers and their associates to life in prison for their roles in a massacre of slum-dwellers during a brutal period of military rule in the early 1990's.
NATIONAL

Overseas Ballots Widen Bush's Lead in Florida Gov. George W. Bush's lead in Florida grew to 930 as absentee ballots from overseas were tallied, but his campaign was unable to claim the victory it had expected as both sides awaited a hearing tomorrow in the Florida Supreme Court.
The parties traded charges of misconduct and manipulation in the counting of absentee ballots cast by Floridians abroad.
The big gains Democrats had hoped for have not yet shown up in Palm Beach and Broward Counties, where the recounts are well under way.
Florida Republicans are homing in on an obscure statute that they believe could give them a decisive hand in choosing the state's 25 electors.
Long before this year's presidential contest turned into a legal imbroglio, Lyndon Johnson's 87-vote victory in a 1948 Senate campaign earned a chapter in electoral lore.
Businesses Resisting Taxes In a fringe movement, businesses are refusing to pay federal taxes, with some success.
Campaign Overhauls Tested ''Full public financing'' intended to reduce campaign spending has been put to the test in three states.
College Presidents' Pay The president of the University of Pennsylvania earned more than $650,000 in 1998-99, topping a list of university presidents with steadily climbing compensation packages.
Safety Effort to Begin More than 10,000 police departments will begin a campaign to enforce laws on drunken driving and the use of child car seats.
NEW YORK/REGION

Fewer Hear Call to Priesthood, And Catholics Face a Shortage New Catholic priests are in short supply nationwide as career choices have become more plentiful, the priesthood has been demoralized by pedophilia scandals, and the work of a priest has become more demanding and more stressful. The bishop of Brooklyn and Queens said the shortage was so severe that each parish in the diocese must report its membership numbers and needs in preparation for possible mergers and cutbacks.
Planning for Global Warming People in corporations and government are quietly beginning to plan for a future in which climate and geography may be different.
